bioghist.p: Mineralogist, crystallographer, lecturer, collector, research scientist, and member of the staff of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, Samuel Gordon took his first course in mineralogy with Edgar T. Wherry at the Wagner Free Institute of Science, 1911-12. He went on to train himself by private study, taking special courses at the University of Pennsylvania and elsewhere. This training culminated in a six months sojourn in Heidelberg, Germany, where he studied with Victor Goldschmidt, 1926-27. His specialized interest in crystallography resulted in the publication, with Victor Goldschmidt as senior author, of the Crystallographic Tables, as the Academy of Natural Science of Philadelphia Special Publication, no. 2. Gordon studied possible collecting localities where minerals could be found to round out the Academy's Vaux collections. His expeditions included trips to the Andes of Peru, Bolivia, and Chile, 1921; the Julianehaab District of Greenland, 1923; Bolivia and Chile, 1925; and the Chilean Expedition of 1938.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of several parts. Collection 90-020 contains 1) professional correspondence, alphabetically arranged, chiefly for the years 1933-1947; 2) Gordon's annotated thesis for the Philadelphia Mineralogical Society titled "Classification of Minerals" (1913); 3) notebooks titled "Krystall Messung I," "Krystall Messung II" (1926), "Lothrorh Practicum," and one untitled notebook of mineralogical tables, all of these notebooks are in German; 4) materials related to Gordon's collecting expeditions, including visas, general correspondence, expense sheets, an herbarium sheet prepared by Harry Trudell bearing the title with blue pencil to which a photograph of Gordon and motorcycle have been affixed; 5) miscellaneous materials including photographs of jade in an envelope titled "Jade by Samuel Gordon for Frontiers." Collection 92-013 consists of proof sheets for an article entitled "Mineralogy of Pennsylvania," published by the Academy of Natural Sciences, 1922. The proof sheets are lightly annotated and several pages are missing. Collection 92-014 is a reprint of Gordon's "Penroseite and Trudellite: two new minerals," first published in the Proceedings of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, Vol. LXXVII, 1925, pages 317-324.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
